key_points: Cybersecurity expert Lisa Donnan experienced fuel shortages due to a cyber-attack on the Colonial Pipeline, serving as a stark reminder of escalating cyber threats.
Recent cyber-attacks in the US and globally have targeted critical infrastructure and services, notably shutting down JBS, the world's largest meat processor, and affecting schools and hospitals.
US officials highlight Russia's role in the surge of ransomware attacks, which President Biden plans to address in a summit with President Putin.
There is a push for NATO to enhance its cyberdefense capabilities in response to the growing threats.
Experts note a significant increase in ransomware attacks, with a 62% global rise since 2019 and a 158% spike in North America.
The COVID-19 pandemic has exacerbated vulnerabilities due to increased digital adaptation and remote work, alongside a boom in insecure software development.
Cybercriminals often face minimal consequences, with cryptocurrencies facilitating anonymous ransom payments.
The US is not only a major target for cyber-attacks but also the biggest spender on cybersecurity, with significant budget allocations for defense.
Notable cyber-attacks have exploited tools developed by the US National Security Agency (NSA), revealing internal vulnerabilities.
Despite increased spending on cybersecurity, challenges in prosecuting cybercriminals and international cooperation persist.
spokespersons: Eric Green (Senior director for Russia and Central Asia, National Security Council)
Steven Pifer (Former deputy assistant secretary of state for European and Eurasian affairs, Senior fellow at the Brookings Institution)
